body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. EUGENE WHELAN Guilty of Serial Hugging ''He was no saint!'' said Eugene Whelan's mother, Joan, her laughter bubbling up. ''Yeah, he could be a giant pain!'' her husband, Alfred, added, chuckling about the ninth of their 10 children. But examples eluded them.
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICTIMS; A Mr. Fix-It in Brooklyn, A Dedicated Traveler, A Model of Self-Discipline

author: Vince Passaro is a novelist living in New York City.
body: We have a tendency to measure the life of New York by the habits and welfare of the upper-middle classes, which is rather like taking all your weather reports from 25,000 feet in the air. The vast majority of New Yorkers make less than $40,000 per year. This is their city too, though that version of New York doesn't have a series yet on HBO.
title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: Sightlines; The View From Out Here

body: Tuller Premium Food, 199 Court Street (Bergen Street), in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is a tiny shop, so it chooses its cheeses carefully -- and there are gems among the 100 on display. They include Borough Market Stilton ($11.99 a pound); Cheddar and Cheshire from England ($11.99 a pound); Pleasant Ridge Reserve, a Gruyère-style Wisconsin cheese
title: FOOD STUFF; In a Small Brooklyn Store, A Trove of 100 Cheeses

body: NEW YORK is forever disappearing. We live amid many lost cities: F. Scott Fitzgerald's glittering, white boomtown. E. B. White's hot, haunting August of 1948. The small society of the midcentury eccentric Joe Gould. Dan Wakefield's Greenwich Village of the 50's. There's also that perennial vision of a livable place with quiet museum galleries and
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Lost City, Reborn for Now

body: ON Wednesday, Abraham Shirinzada, an Afghan coffee vendor, stood in the garage on 30th Street in Manhattan where he stores his cart and spoke about the concern his customers have shown after the attacks. Some have overtipped him to make up for the days he didn't work that week. Others have gently asked if his wife and children in New Jersey have
title: REVERBERATIONS; Small Change, Big Acts of Kindness

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

body: SHE refuses to remove her scarf. But Efrah, a Muslim woman who lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is still afraid because she has heard stories of women in hijab (Arabic for veil) who have been attacked and called names. It was Efrah's fear that made her ask that her last name not be given in this column. She will not ride a subway or a bus. And
title: COPING; Trying to Soothe The Fears Hiding Behind the Veil

body: LOUIS CRANDALL is slow to change his mind. It wasn't until he was inching his way down the stairs from the 25th floor of 1 World Trade Center that he decided: ''Gosh darn it, I was not going to take the Delta Shuttle to Washington this afternoon. I was taking Amtrak.'' When he got to the sixth floor, where the sprinklers were working, he said, ''My
title: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; A Forecaster's Art Takes a Sharp Turn

body: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood yesterday at 233, and the city medical examiner has identified 170; 5,422 are listed as missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives. Confirmed Dead PAUL V. RIZZA A Passion for Cooking Paul V. Rizza learned to cook from his father. They would cook together
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; From Those Left Behind, Remembrances of Love, Hopes and Caring

body: On a quiet block in Brooklyn Heights yesterday, a small cluster of men and boys gathered inside a mosque for afternoon prayers. Outside, a man drove past slowly and yelled, ''Murderers.'' In Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, during the peak late-morning shopping hours, just a few women visited stores in their long gowns and veils. Usually, on such a sunny
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: RELATIONS; Arabs and Muslims Steer Through an Unsettling Scrutiny

body: This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County today. All are Democratic primary choices except for the borough presidency in Staten Island, where there is only a Republican primary. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Mayor Mark Green Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum Comptroller William

body: Elizabeth Dempsey wanted to avoid the College Board tests and other pressures of the last two years of high school. Gillian Grude was seeking more serious students like herself, eager to talk about their ideas in class. And Rizwan Munawar wanted to shorten the long path to becoming a doctor. They were among the students who jumped aboard New York
title: Getting an Early Jump on College; The First 260 in the City's Newest School Experiment

body: Among the myriad open City Council seats this year, few have attracted as many candidates with the political credentials and connections as those in the six-way race in the Democratic primary in the 39th Council District. The candidates' résumés cover the spectrum of local politics in what is commonly known as brownstone Brooklyn, but their names
title: Boasts in 6-Way Race: Experience and Endorsements

body: Brooklyn voters have a chance this year to enliven New York's City Council with the kind of energy, intelligence and independence unrivaled in city politics in many years. Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary. 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David
title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: What does Angela Yurman know about the Battle of Brooklyn? ''Just living in Brooklyn is a battle every day,'' she says. In fact, Mrs. Yurman, 59, is well aware that she has been surrounded by ghosts of the battle her entire life. She grew up across the street from the Old Stone House on the edge of Park Slope, a reconstruction of a 1699 Dutch
title: Washington Fought Here; Who Knew?; On 225th Anniversary, Battle of Brooklyn Is Little-Known Chapter

body: FOOSE-Thomas Trentman. Died in Cobble Hill Nursing Home August 16. A longtime resident of Brooklyn Heights, and before that Manhattan. Born and raised in Dayton, OH, he would have been 84 on September 10. He was an only child. His sole surviving relative is Martha June Baker, who resides in Dayton. He served four years in the Armed Forces in the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FOOSE, THOMAS TRENTMAN

body: In this most crowded of primary seasons, no major race is shaping up to be more crowded than that for public advocate, a position that has existed for less than a decade. But even though so many candidates are aspiring to an office that sometimes looks as if it involves little more than needling the mayor, few New Yorkers seem to know or care who
title: Packed Race For an Office Few Voters Understand

body: Unless you actually do live in a cave, chances are you noticed how hot it was yesterday. In fact, by 8 a.m. in Central Park it was already past 80 degrees. By noon it was past 90. At 2 p.m., according to the National Weather Service, the city reached the day's high of 99 degrees. In hot parlance, that means torrid, blazing, sultry, boiling,
title: 99degrees Heat Was the New York State of Mind

body: ON the northwest edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant -- bordering the bodegas and housing projects of DeKalb Avenue, but only three blocks from the Italianate brownstones and Victorian mansions of Clinton Hill -- six former factories built on a street called Taaffe Place at the turn of the last century have been reincarnated as beautifully renovated
title: When New Homes Drive Out Old Jobs

body: The Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, which has been closed for seven months, recently announced that it was preparing to reopen. But while the 154-year-old national historic landmark on Montague Street has long been covered in scaffolding, it has also been mired in dissent, and church officials do not agree on whether it is safe to open at
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; Wall Cracks Are Just a Hint Of a Revered Church's Woes

body: When the long-troubled John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, closed its doors for good a week ago today, the goodbyes were tinged with a mix of emotions. Some students and teachers at the academically struggling school said they believed that they were being forced out by middle-class neighborhood parents looking for a new school for their
title: Reinventing John Jay High Amid Charges of Exclusion

body: Last summer, a filmmaker named Joe McCarthy set out to make a movie about the Battle of Brooklyn, one of the bloodiest but most overlooked episodes of the American Revolution. Mr. McCarthy did not have much of a budget for sets and soldiers. So he shot the film almost entirely on the locations where the skirmishes were fought, many of which are in
title: Low-Budget Battle of Brooklyn To Be Refought in Film Debut

body: With warm weather, so many things return to New York: the tourists to the subways, the fans to the baseball stadiums, the blue crabs to the Hudson. But the warmth brings back something else, a lot more technical, a lot less welcome and yet just as inseparable from summer in the city: the perfect temperatures for freshly poured concrete and asphalt
title: You Can't Get There From Here: Summer Brings Lots More Road Work; Cabbies Sigh as Workers in Trenches Dig, Repair and Repave

body: Time seems to have forgotten Columbia Street, a tattered roadway at the western edge of Cobble Hill where ghostly trolley tracks and Belgian blocks that once paved the road can still be found poking through the worn asphalt. But the city's Department of Transportation has a plan that officials say will invigorate the part of the street that runs
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL/CARROLL GARDENS; A Wider Street Is (a) Safer (b) More Congested

body: The Swedish furniture retailer Ikea, whose stores are so large that they provide customers with maps, has outlets in Russia and China, in Slovakia and Saudi Arabia. But it does not have a store in New York City, and for now, it will not. Ikea's plan to buy a nine-acre site near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn and build a 300,000-square-foot store
title: Ikea Scrapping Plans for Store Amid Resistance by Neighbors

body: A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. ''Coming Soon,'' the sign says, ''Starbucks Coffey.'' Both a play on words and a joking reference to the neighborhood's nascent gentrification, the sign does not seem an accurate prediction -- at least not yet. With a long history
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken

body: Like most people who spend their days on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, a two-mile stretch of water that starts at the mouth of New York Harbor and dead-ends in South Brooklyn, Dan Kinney used to run for cover when barges came through, kicking up the putrid refuse that had settled on the bottom. ''Run for the nearest building and close the door!''
title: Once a Mess, Canal Aspires To Beauty Now

body: ''We provide a new bathroom without ripping anything out of the old one -- and at about one-ninetieth of the cost,'' said Paul Echavarria, an owner of Premium Reglazing in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Reglazing is a sprayed-on new skin of acrylic urethane that covers tubs, sinks, tile walls, even tile floors. The porcelainlike finish, which comes in 100
title: CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?; When the Glaze Is Off the Bathroom

body: To the Editor: About the naming of Cobble Hill in Brooklyn [''A Landmark Area With a Family Bent,'' May 6] ''by a real estate agent who sought to increase the market potential of the brownstone-lined streets.'': According to a local journalist quoted in the article, ''Everyone has forgotten who that person was.'' Not everyone. It was Sori Kuralt,
title: The Mystery Of Cobble Hill

body: THE name conjures up images of peaceful 19th-century residential streets, which in many ways are still present. But the only cobblestones near the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn -- one of the oldest residential neighborhoods in the borough -- can be found in a largely industrial area just west of the neighborhood on a street named Tiffany Place.
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cobble Hill; A Landmark Area With a Family Bent

body: When Guillaume de Machaut wrote his setting of the Mass, probably in the 1360's, he was creating the first big composition in musical history and setting in motion a process that still continues. Why he should have done such a thing is uncertain. It was long thought that an event so momentous must have had a momentous prompt: the coronation of
title: MUSIC REVIEW; The Composition That Started It All, Gently

body: To the Editor: I was puzzled by the tone of this piece. While Robert Frank's world-class 1950's photography of national anomie has earned him the right to be modest, why are his works described as ''so many dinosaur bones'' in the National Gallery? LAURA HAPKE Cobble Hill, Brooklyn
title: Immobile on the Subway; A Great Photographer, And Not So Obscure

body: ROBERTSON-John Krohn, 29, of Brooklyn, NY, died Wednesday, February 28, 2001. title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROBERTSON, JOHN KROHN
